title_sort: walt whitman to john and ursula burroughs, 11 july [1878]
title: Walt Whitman to John and Ursula Burroughs, 11 July [1878]
text: 431 Stevens st Camden N JJuly 11 p mDear John & 'Sula Burroughs,I kept staying & staying in N YNew York—but left yesterday in the 4 p m train, had a fine run to Phila:Philadelphia & here I am to-daytoday in my regular den—all the better for my month's trip—Nothing very new—brother & sister well as usual—my two nieces, Jeff's daughters, are here & are a great comfort to me. Hot weather, awful—yet I am standing it well so far. I suppose you got the Tribune of July 4 with my letter in. And the box of Graham biscuits by Express—(Of course you know they must be soak'd half an hour or more in milk or water—I sweeten mine with sugar, but some dont like it)—How are you getting along this hot weather? & how is that baby?Walt WhitmanI eat my biscuits for supper only—have two or three of them in a bowl soak'd for an hour, & the water pour'd off, & then a little milk, & plenty of sugar—they must be fixed just right, or they ain't good— Walt Whitman to John and Ursula Burroughs, 11 July [1878]
